title: Pulleys on a Table

children.value: Figure 0 shows the cross section of a smooth table ABCD, standing on the floor AD, with smooth pulleys attached at B and C. Particles of masses $\vari{m_1}$ $<$ $\vari{m_2}$ $<$ $\vari{m_3}$ are attached to a light, inelastic, inextensible string which passes over the pulleys as shown. The system is released from rest with the string taut when $\vari{m_2}$ is a height $\vari{h_{0}}$ from the floor.

answer.value:
$\displaystyle a = \frac{(m_{2} - m_{1})g}{m_{1} + m_{2} + m_{3}} = a_{0} $

is the initial acceleration.

children.value: Find the initial acceleration of the system.

answer.value:
This step can be simplified by a realisation based on energy principles. When 
$\vari{m_{2}}$
 hits the floor there is no longer any tension in the string, but the other two masses have momenta that will carry them onwards and make the string slack. But 
$\vari{m_{1}}$
 now has a net force of 
$\vari{-m_{1}g}$
 acting on it, which will slow both masses and reverse their motion. When they get back to the point they were at as 
$\vari{m_{2}}$
 hit the ground, the string will go taut again. Since the surface is smooth the kinetic energy of 
$\vari{m_{1}}$
 and 
$\vari{m_{3}}$
 must be the same as it was initially; there are no losses to friction and the gravitational potential energy is unchanged. Thus the speed of 
$\vari{m_{1}}$
 and 
$\vari{m_{3}}$
 the instant the string goes taut must be the speed the masses were moving at as 
$\vari{m_{2}}$
 hit the ground.

children.value:
The mass 
$\vari{m_{2}}$
 hits the floor. Describe the subsequent motion of the system until the string again becomes taut.

Find the following quantities, given that 
$\valuedef{m_{1}}{1}{kg,}$
$\valuedef{m_{2}}{3}{kg,}$
$\valuedef{m_{3}}{5}{kg}$
 and 
$\valuedef{h_{0}}{0.45}{m}$
:
the velocity with which the system will move just after the string again becomes taut,

the impulse on 
$\vari{m_{2}}$
 at this instant,
the resulting loss of kinetic energy.

Show that, when the system next comes instantaneously to rest, 
$\vari{m_{2}}$
 will be 
$\vari{\frac{4}{9}h_{0}}$
 above the floor.
